docs.lead_paragraph: SCHULTE--Vivian S. Died peacefully at her home in Manalapan, FL on July 21, 2015. She was 97 years old. An avid tennis player and fan, music lover and food journalist, Vivian was also an author of poetry and won several awards for her work. Vivian was born in New York City, daughter of the late Dr. Simon L. Sternfield and Pauline Tonkonogy Sternfield. A devoted wife to the late Arthur Schulte for 40 years, Vivian leaves behind an extended family of grandchildren, great grandchildren, nephews and a grand nephew and grand niece. She received a B.A. degree from Hunter College, an M.A. degree from Columbia University, and a Ph.D. from New York University. In 1941 she became Food Consultant and Lecturer for L. Bamberger and Co. in Newark and conducted a radio program on Nutrition for WOR during World War II to help homemakers make the most of available foods. She conducted classes in nutrition and food preservation in Newark under the auspices of the American Red Cross. She also served as Food and Home Editor for Fawcett, Hearst and Curtis Publications. Vivian won the American Dairy Association Award for distinguished food journalism. She was a member of Pi Lambda Theta, Honor Society of the Education profession and Kappa Omicron Nu, Honor Society of the Home Economics profession. Vivian was a member of the following: New York Academy of Sciences, American Dietetic Association, Greater New York Dietetic Association, Food and Nutrition Council of New York, American Home Economics Association and Les Dames DEscoffier; and was, in her later years, frequently found with friends at one of her favorite clubs, La Coquille in Manalapan, FL. Dr. Schulte, as she liked to be referred to, was an avid fan of the Metropolitan Opera and was known to participate from her seat from time to time. She was most proud in her later years of her poetry, for which she won numerous awards and was recognized in various publications. Dr. Schulte is survived by 5 grandchildren: Margot Levinson Gantz, Drew Levinson, John Levinson, Lucy Schulte Danziger, Peter Schulte; nine great grandchildren and four nephews: Tom, John, Mark and Jonathan Sternfield. There will be a memorial service held in the fall in New York. In lieu of flowers, please consider memorial donations to: The Hunter College Foundation; memo: Mothers Day Scholarship Fund in Honor of Vivian Schulte, at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, Room E1313, New York, New York 10065. 1/3

docs.lead_paragraph: The House has left town for its August recess and the Senate is departing, which leaves a hefty list of unfinished business. Lawmakers have just 10 legislative days in September to ensure that the government stays open.

headline.main: Congress Breaks, Leaving a Fall Full of Deadlines

docs.lead_paragraph: Imprisoned Chinese journalist Gao Yu has been diagnosed with heart problems and a request for parole on medical grounds is pending, her lawyer said Thursday.

headline.main: Lawyer: Jailed Chinese Journalist Gao Yu Has Heart Problems
headline.print_headline: Lawyer: Jailed Chinese Journalist Gao Yu Has Heart Problems

docs.snippet: Imprisoned Chinese journalist Gao Yu has been diagnosed with heart problems and a request for parole on medical grounds is pending, her lawyer said Thursday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mad as a hornet, a bumblebee buzzes her wings in vain against the walls of the vial holding her captive. She alights briefly on the paper tab indicating her number, and then resumes scuttling around her plastic prison.

headline.main: To Bee, or Not to Bee: This Is No Bumbling Insect Audit

headline.main: Eating Spicy Food Linked to a Longer Life
headline.print_headline: Nutrition: The Spice of (a Longer) Life

docs.abstract: Data from 485,000 people in China found that rates of ischemic heart disease, respiratory disease and cancer were all lower in hot-food eaters.
docs.snippet: Data from 485,000 people in China found that rates of ischemic heart disease, respiratory disease and cancer were all lower in hot-food eaters.

docs.lead_paragraph: You don’t have to eat a dinner cooked by Dan Buettner, the author of “The Blue Zones Solution,” to incorporate his advice into your life: a life that will hopefully be longer after reading this.
